ROBINSON TO HELP COACH

High School in Spring
Changing from the procedure
usually followed in other years,
the freshman and sophomore classes
Will continue their rivalry this year
by competing in lacrosse. This
Sport will take the place of the traditional baseball game, which has
been played in former years. The
game will be as important to the
lower classmen as was the baseball
rivalry, however, for- a win in the
Indian game and another sport, such
as track, football or the class-rush,
will grant the first-year men the
Privilege of dropping their regulations.
To Play in December

The lacrosse game will be played
by the two twelves before the football game. This will make the date
sometime after December 10.
The aspirants for the teams are
quite few, according to Norman
Robinson, last year's varsity captain, who, with the last season's
veterans, will coach the squads. The
freshmen, however, have turned out
in a much greater number than
have their rivals. Robinson„in
Speaking of the coming game, urges
candidates to report, saying "The
greener they are, the better." Experience is quite unnecessary, according to his announcement, for a
novice can be taught the fundamentals in the way the game is
Played here, and will not be hampered by some little knowledge he
has gained elsewhere. The candidates are also urged to bring their
°wn sticks, as that part of the equipment is not plentiful enough. The
Other supplies can be furnished,
however.
Official Practices

The official practices for candidates will be held every Tuesday,
Wednesday
and Friday, at four
o clock ;
but the equipment may be
used on other days as well.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 4, 1927

COTILLON CLUB
DANCE SATURDAY
The Cotillon Club will give
a dance Saturday night from
9 until 12 in the Civil Engineering Hall. Music will be
furnished by the famous
Simpson - Morris Orchestra.
The admission will be one
dollar per couple or stag.
This will be the last Cotillon
Club dance before the first
Cotillon which will be held at
the Maryland Casualty Club
House on December 2.

Jay Harriers to
Meet Navy Team
The Cross Country team has just
completed a week of intensive training before leaving for Annapolis
this afternoon. When the team
meets Navy tomorrow a very close
meet is expected.
The course of three and a half
miles is the shortest the Jays will
traverse this year. Because of this
fact Coach Edwards has trained
his men on speed work all week.
The good weather for the past two
weeks has been a great asset to the
Black and Blue runners. Due to
this favorable element all the harriers except Wheeler are in good
shape. However, his ankle is not
expected to keep him from runn'ng Saturday. The first two men
on the team are as good, if not
better, than last year, and the reserve material is much more capable. The middle portion of the
team, however, forms the unknown
quantity and it is on their performance that the meet will depend.

ORGANIZATION OF
TANK TEAM SOON
Dalsemer Schedules Two Home
Meets—Possibility of
Northern Trip
Organization of the swimming
team will take place in about two
weeks' time, according to Donald
Hiss, captain of this year's team.
Practice will begin around December 1.
It is almost a certainty that there
will be a swimming team this year
in spite of reports to the contrary.
Henry Iddens, Business Manager
of Athletics, says that whether a
team will be put into the field of
competition or not depends upon
the success of the football season—
that is the monetary success. So
far, according to Mr. Iddens, the
season has been a very profitable
one and the probability is that
Johns Hopkins will again have a
tank team.
The usual yearly agitation about
a basketball team was again in evidence, but it is obviously impossible
to have a representative on the cou-ft
this late in the season, as most colleges have already completed their
schedules.

CANE CLUB TO HOLD
INITIATION MONDAY
The Cane Club will hold
its annual fall initiation next
Monday at 12.30 on the upper
quadrangle, Ashtin Devereux,
president, stated. The initiates have not as yet been announced.
The customary procession
of carriages, followed by the
"tapping" of the newly elected
members, will take place. After the initiation a luncheon
will be held at the Grey Goose
Inn and a dance given that
night. .

"Columbia has a very powerful
team and we are in for the hardest
game of the season," said Coach
Van Orman, in commenting on tomorrow's game. "Cornell was
lucky in holding Columbia to a tie
last week," added the coach.
George Darley, assistant coach,
who scouted Columbia, asserts that
they have the best charging line
that Hopkins will have to face this
year,
Fine Record

Columbia's record so far this
season has been very impressive,
only thirteen points having been
scored against them. After giving
Union College of Schenectady a
beating they met Colgate, Williams
and Cornell on successive Saturdays. The New Yorkers lost to
Colgate, 13-6, but the loss is not a
serious blot on their record as the
vaunted N. Y. U. team did not even
score against Colgate. Williams
was defeated, 19-0, by Columbia,
and last week's game ended in a
scoreless tie with Cornell.
In commenting on the probable
outcome of the game,Van Orman
said that Columbia was undoubtedly a better team than Syracuse,
which defeated the Jays, 21-6, several weeks ago. However, Hopkins' teamwork has improved greatly since the game with the Orange
and the Jays should put up a better
battle tomorrow than they did last
month.
The fact that Columbia plays
Penn a week after the Hopkins
game is a point in favor of the Jays,
as Columbia will probably keep her
first team out of the game.
Same Line-up

Van Orman will stand pat on the
line-up that gave Delaware a drubbing last week, with the possible
substitution of Ahroon for Schmedike at guard. Kegan will be ready
to play tomorrow, but he will not be
used unless it becomes necessary,
as he has not completely recovered
from the injury suffered in the
Loyola game. Ahroon, however, is
again in good condition.
Kaplan, clever back, who ran wild
against Hopkins two years ago, will
again be in the line-up for Columbia, and his end-runs will be watched closely by the Jay wingmen.
Rieger, a triple-threat back, is one
of the big guns of the New Yorkers' attack, while Madden, a sturdy
defensive back, and Green will complete the ball-toting quartet. Columbia's team is very heavy this
year, averaging around 190 pounds,
and this added weight will give
them a big advantage over the light
Black and Blue eleven.

TIME TO START THINKING ABOUT IT
If Johns Hopkins wins the Intercollegiate lacrosse championship again this year, the team is almost sure to be selected as the
American Olympic representative. It is foolish to predict a
championship before the last game of a schedule has been played,
and it is much more foolish to do so five months before the season
opens, but sometimes it is wise to give the matter some thought.
Hopkins has more than an even chance to repeat. If she does,
and subsequently receives the Olympic selection, eight thousand
dollars will be necessary to send the team abroad. The Athletic
Association hasn't the funds; Heaven knows the University
hasn't. Where are they to come from?
The eight thousand will have to be raised from among the
students and alumni. During the spring the Athletic Association
will probably launch a campaign to insure the funds in the event
of good fortune. Meanwhile, alumni and students, start thinking
about it!

STUDENT GOVERNMENT AT PRINCETON
In prescribing the duties of a Student Council to supersede the
old Senior Council, the Board of Trustees at Princeton University
has acted with great circumspection and foresight. It has recognized definitely the right of students to a clearly articulate voice
in their own affairs, and established the Council with this view
predominant.
The scope of the Student Council at Princeton is broader than
it is here at Hopkins. Its duties include the supervision of practically every phase of undergraduate life. The Council is not
specifically charged with the maintenance of the honor system,
but is "the recognized medium of communication between the
authorities and the students of the University on all questions
of student conduct, student opinion, and in all questions concerning the welfare of the University in which students have a
yoice." The members are accorded both membership and voting
power on certain faculty committees, and are to be called upon
before final action is taken upon any matters of undergraduate
life. If these stipulations be strictly adhered to, and if the judgment of the Student Council is regarded generally as acceptable
and mature, the provisions are highly important. For not only
are the students allowed the prerogative of action in matters that
affect their personal conduct, but they are granted a voice in
practically any matter that affects them at all. It must be assumed,
of course, that the men represented on the Council are of the
very highest type, and that they accept the responsibility of their
positions sincerely.
The powers of the Princeton body are not specified in great
detail, for it was felt that with the passing of time, the Council's
jurisdiction could be enlarged. _Moreover, as the Princetonian
points out, inasmuch as the ultimate responsibility for all phases
of undergraduate life rests with the Board of Trustees, that body
has the final veto.
After the, disastrous end of the Senior Council last spring, the
delegation of the same, and even greater powers to a similar
organization is in the nature of an experiment. We hope it will
be a successful one.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 4, 1927

SPEAKING OF SPORTS
Yale clearly demonstrated Saturday that it has one of the best football teams in the East by defeating
Dartmouth, 19-0.
In Bruce Caldwell the Eli eleven
has one of the finest running backs
in the country, and in selecting AllAmerican teams this year his name
should not be overlooked.
Both teams showed exceptional
offensive strength in the early
stages of the game. But Yale's
defense succeeded in smothering
the heretofore elusive Al Marsters
and Myles Lane after the Greens'
big threat in the opening period.
* * * * *
Johnny Ho ben, at quarterback,
showed excellent generalship in
directing the team's attack. Early
in the season his choice of plays was
severely criticized, but in last week's
game he more than made up for
any mistakes that -he made in previous games.
• *

New York University's chamPionship hopes received a terrible
jolt when Colgate, twice defeated
this season, held the Violet to a
scoreless tie.
Another colossal blow was dealt
the Violet team when
Al Sussman,
the giant tackle who has
been a
bulwark on the defense for the last
two years, was carried off the field
With a broken leg.
This battle, which rivaled the late
war in ferociousness, ivas one of the
hardest-fought games of
the season.
Three N. Y. U. players were carried off the field, while two Colgate
men were forced to leave the contest because of injuries. As a
result both teams are reported to be
in rather poor shape for their games
tomorrow.
* * * * *

Played every minute of all of last

Last Saturday afternoon the Baltimore Naturalists' Field Club conducted its second trip of the season
to the vicinity of Edgewood Arsenal. Doctors Mast and Cowles
headed the expedition, which consisted entirely of graduate students.
At Maxwell Point a veritable
arboretum was discovered on the
grounds of what was formerly a
large mansion. As the trees were
new to most of the members, some
time was consumed in examining
them.
Mr. Clark obtained a few minnows and sea gammans with his
hand net, while Dr. Cowles examined with interest a formation of
red clay along the shore, known as
pied clay. When moist, this clay
can be molded like putty. Abromavich, the cameraman of the the
party, took several photographs.

Looking forward to its annual
football game with the sophomores,
the freshman eleven is slowly but
steadily rounding into good shape.
So excellent has been the material
applying for regular berths, that
Coach Ray Van Orman has advanced three of the candidates to
the varsity squad. These men,
members of the backfield, are Gibson, Mallard and Mezzulo ; they
have shown fine ability.
The team has organized and has
elected as its manager Heizlinger,
who was graduated from Poly last
year. Clayton, a regular of last
year's varsity eleven, is coaching
them.
Hold Scrimmage

Staging a scrimmage with the
junior varsity, the freshman team
held them to four touchdowns. This
showing encouraged the coaches,
who are satisfied with the progress
to date.
Manager Heizlinger is attempting
to book games with Forest Park
high school and the freshman classes
of Mt. St. Mary's and St. John's.
The sophomore class has not as
yet organized its representative
eleven, but practice will soon be
called in order that each team will
be in the best possible shape for the
match. The game is scheduled to
be held during the week of December 12.

TO-DAY in a modern office you
will find these electrical aids:
Addressing Machines; Dictating
Machines; Adding Machines;
Multigraphs; Check-writers; Calculating Machines; Cash Registers; Interior Telephones; Card
Recorders; Card Sorters; Time
Recorders;Accounting Machines;
Time Stamps; Clocks; Mailing
Machines; Typewriters; Fans;
MAZDA Lamps, and many other
electric devices.
This familiar mark
appears on many
electrical products,
including motors
that drive timeand labor-saving
office machines.

•

But visit a modern office! A thousand letters to go out by four
o'clock. A new price list to all
customersin to-night's mail, without
fail. Enter electricity. Two or three
people turnswitches,and thefinished
letters come out of an ingenious
machine. Another motion and they
are sealed and stamped. Only electricity could get that job done.
•

•

•

Here's a statistical job. The reports
are in; thousands of figures to
analyze. Looks like overtime for
fifty clerks. "Certainly not," answers
electricity, as a button starts the

motor-driven sorters and tabulators.
Key cards are punched with lightning fingers. Electric sorters devour
24,000 cards an hour. Tabulators
add quantities and amounts in jig
time, and print the totals.
•

•

•

Go to almost any bank today. Hand
in your account book. Click, click,
click, goes the electric book-keeping
machine and back comes the book
to you. Five operations performed
in that brief moment. Everybody
saves time, —you, the clerk, the
bank,—when electricity is the bookkeeper.
•

•

•

In the office of to-morrow you will
find" electrical fingers" doing more
work than even to-day.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 4, 1927

6

DR. ABEL MAKES
NEW DISCOVERY
Received Prize From Research
Corporation of America
GRADUATE OF STRASBURG
Is Also Author of Well Known
Medical Book
Having formed a heretofore unknown pure crystal insulin, Dr.
John J. Abel, the eminent Professor of Pharmacology, has again
caused the name of the Johns Hopkins -Medical School to be widespread. This composition has proved to be a wonderful success in the
curing of diabetical diseases.
This discovery, along with many
other equally astounding ones, was
the cause of his receiving many
honors and much attention throughout the medical profession. He
was conferred the Willard Gibbs
medal by the American• Chemical
Society, which is the highest honor
that can be given a scientist, for
having_ done for science more than
any other living scientist without
pecuniary advantage to himself,
and for having done most to make
life enjoyable.
Awarded Prize

He was also awarded the first
annual prize of $2,500 from the
Research Corporation of America,
"because of his many scientific contribufons which have benefited humanity." In the voting of both organizations as to whom the medals
should be conferred, Dr. Abel was
selected on the first ballot. The
fact that the honor had never before been conferred on the first ballot is a great tribute to the great
scholar that Dr. Abel is.
Having received• the Willard
Gibbs medal, the Pharmacologist
said, "The human body is a walking drug shop. There are, perhaps,
17 glands in the body which secrete
and pass into the body certain substances. We are just beginning to
understand a little about these
glands and their functions."

STIENWALD TO TAKE
TRIP TO SALISBURY
Osmar Steinwald, student
musical director of the Musical Club, and Bennett Kolb
will take a trip to Denton,
Salisbury and Easton this
week-end. The purpose of
this trip, according to Steinwald, will be to make final arrangements for a concert to
be given by the Club at one of
these cities this winter.
The Musical Club, which
will hold rehearsals on Monday and Thursday nights during November and December,
plans to again visit Norfolk
this year. A definite schedule is expected to be announced in the near future.

DR. FOUILLERAT GIVES
FIRST OF LECTURES
Professor Makes Comparison of
Two of Shakespeare's Works
"Lucrece is a .series of lyrical
suggestions, while 'Venus and
Adonis' is a succession of beautiful
experiences," said Professor Albert
Fouillerat in the first of his series
of lectures. This group of five lectures on Shakespeare, by Professor
Fouillerat, is made possible through
the annual Turnbull Memorial Lec
tures.
According to Dr. Fouillerat,
Shakespeare first began to write
for financial gain. His early attempts were begun with the view of
obtaining a certain wealthy nobleman as a patron. The original
style was influenced by the prevalent aristocratic view of literature.

The Athletic Association is doing
everything in its power to encourage
the early sale of tickets for this
year's Maryland game. This effort
is being made in order to eliminate
the confusion and delay which takes
place every year, due to the late
buying of tickets. Mr. Iddens,
business manager of athletics, is
making a threefold appeal concerning this matter to the Johns Hopkins Alumni, to the student body
and to the merchants of Baltimore.

and one victory by only three points
for Maryland) are given. The
sportsmanlike conduct and lack of
injuries on both sides, despite the
intense rivalry, are stressed. The
alumni are urged to buy their tickets early in order to insure the success of the game, both from an
alumni and a financial standpoint.
Mr. Iddens has reserved section
J, the best in the Stadium, for the
students. He is making a special
appeal to them to purchase their
seats as soon as possible, in order
that the most important game of
the season may be a success from
every point of view. Tickets are
now on sale at the Athletic office.

A Direct Comparison

The forming of pure insulin crystal was not the only remarkable
achievement of the scientist, however. Among his other successes
were the isolation of adrenalin and
the invention of the artific'al kidney. Adrenalin is a drug that
strengthens the heart. It has proved
valuable during operations and severe cases of pneumonia. It has
even been known to restore to life
infants for whom all hope has been
lost.
The artificial kidney is a mechanism which may be used for washing
poisons from the blood of the body.
It, too, has been used very advantageously.

This first talk on the famous poet
and his works was a direct comparison between his "Venus and Adonis" and his "Rape of Lucrece." The
author seemed to have lived in retrospect while writing the former.
He looks back upon the simplicity
of the primeval race and allows
that to guide his style. "There is
nothing artificial about the whole
work," Mr. Fouillerat stated.
It begins at sunrise with all the
beauty of nature expressed in the
lyrical lines. Shakespeare here displays his marvelous power of vivid
description in the fewest words
with the most striking effect.
Throughout the whole one sees
nothing but superb beauty.
"The Rape of Lucrece," differing from "Venus and Adonis,"
shows that Shakespeare had acquired.a greater knowledge of the
vices of the world. The images
brought about by the rhetorical excursions are indeed striking. Even
the blush of Lucrece lends the author an excuse for a passage on
virtue.

Discovered Epinephrine

Darkness Is Employed

Another notable discovery was
made by the Pharmacologist about
twenty years ago. This was the
discovery of Epinephrine, which is
the active principle of a gland situated above the kidneys, known as
the suprarenal gland.
The scientist has contributed to
science in another way than that of
scientific discoveries. He is the author of "The Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics." This book is considered equal
to or better than any book of similar contents.
Dr. Abel, who is a graduate of
the University of Michigan and
the University of Strasburg, has
been connected with the Medical
School since 1893. He is now preparing to complete the analysis of
the chemical composition of the insulin crystal.

Lucrece is ghastly in most of its
setting. Darkness is employed to
lend the atmosphere of terror and
evil. "Venus and Adonis," however, relies on light and nature for
its poetry.
Venus is cynical and sensual in
some places almost to an extreme.
Lucrece consists of a tirade against
lust and evil. It seems as if it
were an apology for the sensuality
of Venus and Adonis.
Besides the theme there is a subtler poetry in the visions in Lucrece.
This latter work is interesting, not
only because of its dramatic points,
but also it is the link between the
earlier work, "Venus and Adonis,"
and the lyrical genius expressed in
the sonnets.
The next lecture will be held this
afternoon in the Civil Engineering
Hall at 5 o'clock.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 4, 1927

COTILLON CLUB
DANCE SATURDAY
The Cotillon Club will give
a dance Saturday night from
9 until 12 in the Civil Engineering Hall. Music will be
furnished by the famous
Simpson - Morris Orchestra.
The admission will be one
dollar per couple or stag.
This will be the last Cotillon
Club dance before the first
Cotillon which will be held at
the Maryland Casualty Club
House on December 2.

Jay Harriers to
Meet Navy Team
The Cross Country team has just
completed a week of intensive training before leaving for Annapolis
this afternoon. When the team
meets Navy tomorrow a very close
meet is expected.
The course of three and a half
miles is the shortest the Jays will
traverse this year. Because of this
fact Coach Edwards has trained
his men on speed work all week.
The good weather for the past two
weeks has been a great asset to the
Black and Blue runners. Due to
this favorable element all the harriers except Wheeler are in good
shape. However, his ankle is not
expected to keep him from runn'ng Saturday. The first two men
on the team are as good, if not
better, than last year, and the reserve material is much more capable. The middle portion of the
team, however, forms the unknown
quantity and it is on their performance that the meet will depend.

ORGANIZATION OF
TANK TEAM SOON
Dalsemer Schedules Two Home
Meets—Possibility of
Northern Trip
Organization of the swimming
team will take place in about two
weeks' time, according to Donald
Hiss, captain of this year's team.
Practice will begin around December 1.
It is almost a certainty that there
will be a swimming team this year
in spite of reports to the contrary.
Henry Iddens, Business Manager
of Athletics, says that whether a
team will be put into the field of
competition or not depends upon
the success of the football season—
that is the monetary success. So
far, according to Mr. Iddens, the
season has been a very profitable
one and the probability is that
Johns Hopkins will again have a
tank team.
The usual yearly agitation about
a basketball team was again in evidence, but it is obviously impossible
to have a representative on the cou-ft
this late in the season, as most colleges have already completed their
schedules.

CANE CLUB TO HOLD
INITIATION MONDAY
The Cane Club will hold
its annual fall initiation next
Monday at 12.30 on the upper
quadrangle, Ashtin Devereux,
president, stated. The initiates have not as yet been announced.
The customary procession
of carriages, followed by the
"tapping" of the newly elected
members, will take place. After the initiation a luncheon
will be held at the Grey Goose
Inn and a dance given that
night. .

"Columbia has a very powerful
team and we are in for the hardest
game of the season," said Coach
Van Orman, in commenting on tomorrow's game. "Cornell was
lucky in holding Columbia to a tie
last week," added the coach.
George Darley, assistant coach,
who scouted Columbia, asserts that
they have the best charging line
that Hopkins will have to face this
year,
Fine Record

Columbia's record so far this
season has been very impressive,
only thirteen points having been
scored against them. After giving
Union College of Schenectady a
beating they met Colgate, Williams
and Cornell on successive Saturdays. The New Yorkers lost to
Colgate, 13-6, but the loss is not a
serious blot on their record as the
vaunted N. Y. U. team did not even
score against Colgate. Williams
was defeated, 19-0, by Columbia,
and last week's game ended in a
scoreless tie with Cornell.
In commenting on the probable
outcome of the game,Van Orman
said that Columbia was undoubtedly a better team than Syracuse,
which defeated the Jays, 21-6, several weeks ago. However, Hopkins' teamwork has improved greatly since the game with the Orange
and the Jays should put up a better
battle tomorrow than they did last
month.
The fact that Columbia plays
Penn a week after the Hopkins
game is a point in favor of the Jays,
as Columbia will probably keep her
first team out of the game.
Same Line-up

Van Orman will stand pat on the
line-up that gave Delaware a drubbing last week, with the possible
substitution of Ahroon for Schmedike at guard. Kegan will be ready
to play tomorrow, but he will not be
used unless it becomes necessary,
as he has not completely recovered
from the injury suffered in the
Loyola game. Ahroon, however, is
again in good condition.
Kaplan, clever back, who ran wild
against Hopkins two years ago, will
again be in the line-up for Columbia, and his end-runs will be watched closely by the Jay wingmen.
Rieger, a triple-threat back, is one
of the big guns of the New Yorkers' attack, while Madden, a sturdy
defensive back, and Green will complete the ball-toting quartet. Columbia's team is very heavy this
year, averaging around 190 pounds,
and this added weight will give
them a big advantage over the light
Black and Blue eleven.

TIME TO START THINKING ABOUT IT
If Johns Hopkins wins the Intercollegiate lacrosse championship again this year, the team is almost sure to be selected as the
American Olympic representative. It is foolish to predict a
championship before the last game of a schedule has been played,
and it is much more foolish to do so five months before the season
opens, but sometimes it is wise to give the matter some thought.
Hopkins has more than an even chance to repeat. If she does,
and subsequently receives the Olympic selection, eight thousand
dollars will be necessary to send the team abroad. The Athletic
Association hasn't the funds; Heaven knows the University
hasn't. Where are they to come from?
The eight thousand will have to be raised from among the
students and alumni. During the spring the Athletic Association
will probably launch a campaign to insure the funds in the event
of good fortune. Meanwhile, alumni and students, start thinking
about it!

STUDENT GOVERNMENT AT PRINCETON
In prescribing the duties of a Student Council to supersede the
old Senior Council, the Board of Trustees at Princeton University
has acted with great circumspection and foresight. It has recognized definitely the right of students to a clearly articulate voice
in their own affairs, and established the Council with this view
predominant.
The scope of the Student Council at Princeton is broader than
it is here at Hopkins. Its duties include the supervision of practically every phase of undergraduate life. The Council is not
specifically charged with the maintenance of the honor system,
but is "the recognized medium of communication between the
authorities and the students of the University on all questions
of student conduct, student opinion, and in all questions concerning the welfare of the University in which students have a
yoice." The members are accorded both membership and voting
power on certain faculty committees, and are to be called upon
before final action is taken upon any matters of undergraduate
life. If these stipulations be strictly adhered to, and if the judgment of the Student Council is regarded generally as acceptable
and mature, the provisions are highly important. For not only
are the students allowed the prerogative of action in matters that
affect their personal conduct, but they are granted a voice in
practically any matter that affects them at all. It must be assumed,
of course, that the men represented on the Council are of the
very highest type, and that they accept the responsibility of their
positions sincerely.
The powers of the Princeton body are not specified in great
detail, for it was felt that with the passing of time, the Council's
jurisdiction could be enlarged. _Moreover, as the Princetonian
points out, inasmuch as the ultimate responsibility for all phases
of undergraduate life rests with the Board of Trustees, that body
has the final veto.
After the, disastrous end of the Senior Council last spring, the
delegation of the same, and even greater powers to a similar
organization is in the nature of an experiment. We hope it will
be a successful one.

Last Saturday afternoon the Baltimore Naturalists' Field Club conducted its second trip of the season
to the vicinity of Edgewood Arsenal. Doctors Mast and Cowles
headed the expedition, which consisted entirely of graduate students.
At Maxwell Point a veritable
arboretum was discovered on the
grounds of what was formerly a
large mansion. As the trees were
new to most of the members, some
time was consumed in examining
them.
Mr. Clark obtained a few minnows and sea gammans with his
hand net, while Dr. Cowles examined with interest a formation of
red clay along the shore, known as
pied clay. When moist, this clay
can be molded like putty. Abromavich, the cameraman of the the
party, took several photographs.

Looking forward to its annual
football game with the sophomores,
the freshman eleven is slowly but
steadily rounding into good shape.
So excellent has been the material
applying for regular berths, that
Coach Ray Van Orman has advanced three of the candidates to
the varsity squad. These men,
members of the backfield, are Gibson, Mallard and Mezzulo ; they
have shown fine ability.
The team has organized and has
elected as its manager Heizlinger,
who was graduated from Poly last
year. Clayton, a regular of last
year's varsity eleven, is coaching
them.
Hold Scrimmage

Staging a scrimmage with the
junior varsity, the freshman team
held them to four touchdowns. This
showing encouraged the coaches,
who are satisfied with the progress
to date.
Manager Heizlinger is attempting
to book games with Forest Park
high school and the freshman classes
of Mt. St. Mary's and St. John's.
The sophomore class has not as
yet organized its representative
eleven, but practice will soon be
called in order that each team will
be in the best possible shape for the
match. The game is scheduled to
be held during the week of December 12.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 4, 1927

6

DR. ABEL MAKES
NEW DISCOVERY
Received Prize From Research
Corporation of America
GRADUATE OF STRASBURG
Is Also Author of Well Known
Medical Book
Having formed a heretofore unknown pure crystal insulin, Dr.
John J. Abel, the eminent Professor of Pharmacology, has again
caused the name of the Johns Hopkins -Medical School to be widespread. This composition has proved to be a wonderful success in the
curing of diabetical diseases.
This discovery, along with many
other equally astounding ones, was
the cause of his receiving many
honors and much attention throughout the medical profession. He
was conferred the Willard Gibbs
medal by the American• Chemical
Society, which is the highest honor
that can be given a scientist, for
having_ done for science more than
any other living scientist without
pecuniary advantage to himself,
and for having done most to make
life enjoyable.
Awarded Prize

He was also awarded the first
annual prize of $2,500 from the
Research Corporation of America,
"because of his many scientific contribufons which have benefited humanity." In the voting of both organizations as to whom the medals
should be conferred, Dr. Abel was
selected on the first ballot. The
fact that the honor had never before been conferred on the first ballot is a great tribute to the great
scholar that Dr. Abel is.
Having received• the Willard
Gibbs medal, the Pharmacologist
said, "The human body is a walking drug shop. There are, perhaps,
17 glands in the body which secrete
and pass into the body certain substances. We are just beginning to
understand a little about these
glands and their functions."

STIENWALD TO TAKE
TRIP TO SALISBURY
Osmar Steinwald, student
musical director of the Musical Club, and Bennett Kolb
will take a trip to Denton,
Salisbury and Easton this
week-end. The purpose of
this trip, according to Steinwald, will be to make final arrangements for a concert to
be given by the Club at one of
these cities this winter.
The Musical Club, which
will hold rehearsals on Monday and Thursday nights during November and December,
plans to again visit Norfolk
this year. A definite schedule is expected to be announced in the near future.

DR. FOUILLERAT GIVES
FIRST OF LECTURES
Professor Makes Comparison of
Two of Shakespeare's Works
"Lucrece is a .series of lyrical
suggestions, while 'Venus and
Adonis' is a succession of beautiful
experiences," said Professor Albert
Fouillerat in the first of his series
of lectures. This group of five lectures on Shakespeare, by Professor
Fouillerat, is made possible through
the annual Turnbull Memorial Lec
tures.
According to Dr. Fouillerat,
Shakespeare first began to write
for financial gain. His early attempts were begun with the view of
obtaining a certain wealthy nobleman as a patron. The original
style was influenced by the prevalent aristocratic view of literature.

A Direct Comparison

The forming of pure insulin crystal was not the only remarkable
achievement of the scientist, however. Among his other successes
were the isolation of adrenalin and
the invention of the artific'al kidney. Adrenalin is a drug that
strengthens the heart. It has proved
valuable during operations and severe cases of pneumonia. It has
even been known to restore to life
infants for whom all hope has been
lost.
The artificial kidney is a mechanism which may be used for washing
poisons from the blood of the body.
It, too, has been used very advantageously.

This first talk on the famous poet
and his works was a direct comparison between his "Venus and Adonis" and his "Rape of Lucrece." The
author seemed to have lived in retrospect while writing the former.
He looks back upon the simplicity
of the primeval race and allows
that to guide his style. "There is
nothing artificial about the whole
work," Mr. Fouillerat stated.
It begins at sunrise with all the
beauty of nature expressed in the
lyrical lines. Shakespeare here displays his marvelous power of vivid
description in the fewest words
with the most striking effect.
Throughout the whole one sees
nothing but superb beauty.
"The Rape of Lucrece," differing from "Venus and Adonis,"
shows that Shakespeare had acquired.a greater knowledge of the
vices of the world. The images
brought about by the rhetorical excursions are indeed striking. Even
the blush of Lucrece lends the author an excuse for a passage on
virtue.

Discovered Epinephrine

Darkness Is Employed

Another notable discovery was
made by the Pharmacologist about
twenty years ago. This was the
discovery of Epinephrine, which is
the active principle of a gland situated above the kidneys, known as
the suprarenal gland.
The scientist has contributed to
science in another way than that of
scientific discoveries. He is the author of "The Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics." This book is considered equal
to or better than any book of similar contents.
Dr. Abel, who is a graduate of
the University of Michigan and
the University of Strasburg, has
been connected with the Medical
School since 1893. He is now preparing to complete the analysis of
the chemical composition of the insulin crystal.

Lucrece is ghastly in most of its
setting. Darkness is employed to
lend the atmosphere of terror and
evil. "Venus and Adonis," however, relies on light and nature for
its poetry.
Venus is cynical and sensual in
some places almost to an extreme.
Lucrece consists of a tirade against
lust and evil. It seems as if it
were an apology for the sensuality
of Venus and Adonis.
Besides the theme there is a subtler poetry in the visions in Lucrece.
This latter work is interesting, not
only because of its dramatic points,
but also it is the link between the
earlier work, "Venus and Adonis,"
and the lyrical genius expressed in
the sonnets.
The next lecture will be held this
afternoon in the Civil Engineering
Hall at 5 o'clock.
